channel.title: Solving equations with a denomonator
channel.description:
I was just wondering how to go about solving equations with a denomonator.. like the steps to doing it. Here is an example question.
3 - x = 15 4
My teacher gave us some messed up notes, and this is what they say (it's a handout.)
1. Rewrite the equation by getting rid of any brackets first. 2. Get rid of denomonators by doing one of two things: a) If there's a term on each side of the '=' then cross multiply. b) If there's more than one term on a side, find common denomonator for all the terms in equation. 3. Solve as normal.
So I don't know what one of the two to do, because finding the greatest common demonator will keep it as a fraction? :confused: And if I cross multiply a fraction with a number thats messed up. Sorry if you think I'm an idiot I just think our teacher should give better explination in her notes. :o

item.title: Solving equations with a denomonator
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

To solve that, you can understand it to be a fraction multiplying x, and then multiply each side by the fraction’s reciprocal. The reciprocal of a fraction of simlpy the denominator and numerator switched, and therefore is 4/3.

Multilpying 3/4 with 4/3 gives you 12/12 or 1 and multiplying 15 by 4/3 gives you 60/3 or 20. So 20’s your answer.

Alternatively, you can actually view it is a rational equation, which I guess is what your teacher wanted (I prefer the first way). Ie (3x)/4 = 15. In this case, to solve it, multiply each side by 4 to give you 3x = 60. Then divide by 3, giving you x = 20.
